Award.AwardTitle: RUI: NEW ASYMMETRIC SYNTHESES VIA SPIROAMINOBORATES
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this new award, the Chemical Synthesis Program supports Professor Margarita Ortiz of University of Puerto Rico at Humacao in a project investigating the development of new borate based catalysts for the selective preparation of a variety of important chemical substances. Existing catalysts used for these purposes are often expensive, difficult to purify, highly sensitive to air and moisture, and harmful to the environment. This project will design and prepare catalysts that are readily and inexpensively available, easy to handle and environmentally friendly. Since the research will be carried out by undergraduates, it will be an excellent way to train a new generation of Puerto Rican scientists.

This project will investigate the preparation of new chiral spiroamino borate esters to be used for the chemo- and stereoselective asymmetric reduction of ketones and their derivatives. These studies are designed to provide fundamental knowledge of the enantioselective catalytic reduction of these substrates and to establish new protocols for the chiral synthesis of amino acids and alcohols.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Final Project Outcomes Report 

Impact on the development of the principal discipline of the project?

     The general aim of our project was to design and develop new chiral organoborane reagents and novel synthetic transformations that could accomplish high enantioselectivities in organic synthesis. Our project involved the design of new asymmetric reactions via environmentally benign boron compounds and reactions ?on water? that will open a facile access to non-racemic alcohols, amines, amino alcohols and amino acids of industrial and biological importance.

       In addition, our project provided under-represented undergraduate students, mainly women, with an exceptional training in advanced organic synthesis using modern methods and up to date instrumental techniques.

       Previously, our group discovered an important family of relatively air stable spiroaminoborate esters derived from nonracemic amino alcohols for the asymmetric synthesis of a wide variety of aromatic and heterocyclic alcohols and amines using less than 10% of catalysts under mild conditions with excellent enantioselectivities. Catalyst 1 and 2 were found to be highly enantioselective for the reduction of arylalkyl ketones, while catalyst 3 was the most effective for O-benzyloximes reduction. These asymmetric methods have been internationally recognized (Org. Synth. 2010, 87, 26-35; Spiroborates-nihms169020) by their innovation and convenience for multigram scale synthesis.

      We have now developed an asymmetric synthesis of novel chiral 1,2-amino alcohols by the regioselective ring opening of chiral epoxides.  The scope and limitations of the new regio- and stereoselective ring opening of chiral epoxides by sodium azide under hydrolytic conditions was studied. Our method offered a new synthetic tool to prepare chiral 1,2-amino alcohols, which are very important molecules as precursors for the synthesis of other chiral compounds. Interestingly, under neutral hydrolytic conditions the azide ion attacks the monosubstituted oxiranes, preferentially, at the more substituted a position with complete inversion of configuration, providing only one regioisomer. It seems that this stereoselective ring-opening reaction by azide takes place by an SN2 type mechanism, acting hot water as a moderate Lewis acid. To the best of our knowledge, there are no uncatalyzed methods for the synthesis of nonracemic β-azido alcohols via ring-opening of enantiopure monosubstituted epoxides in hot water. (?Synthesis of enantiopure 1,2-azido and 1,2-amino alcohols via regio and stereoselective ring-opening of enantiopure epoxides by sodium azide in hot water?, by Hai-Yang Wang, Kun Huang, Melvin De Jes?s, Sandraliz Espinosa, Luis E. Pi?ero-Santiago, Charles L. Barnes, Margarita Ortiz-Marciales;  Tetrahedron: Asymm., 2016, 27, 91-100).

      We have also developed a new method for the enantioselective synthesis of key chiral 1-aryl-3-chloropropanol and their corresponding chiral oxetanes with excellent enantioselectivity and good isolated yield of the pure products, that were fully characterized. The ring opening of the oxetanes under different reaction conditions to obtain chiral 1,3-azido alcohols and amino alcohols, gave a mixture of products. A publication in Tetrahedron Asymmetry on the synthesis of enantiopure oxetanes will be submitted soon.

 

Impact on other disciplines?

    The development of a new method for the enantioselective synthesis of chiral boron catalysts and chiral cyclic amines will contribute to the preparation of important chiral drugs. The development of new amino compounds can be useful in the synthesis of semiconductor materials and pharmaceutical products.

Impact on the development of human resources?

    More than twelve Undergraduate students were trained in advanced research techniques and developed knowledge and skills in advanced organic synthetic methods and advanced chemical research. Besides, our students were motivated to learn advanced instrumental techniques (NMR, FTIR, GC-MS, polarimetry), technical writing and research ethics. In addition, they received great stimulus to continue toward summer research and graduate studies. Four are in graduate schools.

Impact on physical resources that form infrastructure?

   Our group has now a new modern organic research laboratory with space for about 10 undergraduate students and two research technicians. In addition, a modern instrumentation facility with modern instruments near to our laboratory is also available to our research group.
